an MC with a mic got hit by the wind and said "oh it hit me".
i thought "serves you right", but it hit me too, so i time leaped back again.

there was a small dog like a chihuahua, genetically modified to urinate 12 m (40 ft). even from a distance, its urine flew over and splashed on me.
i time leaped and went back a little.
it flew maybe 50 m (150 ft), or even 100 m (300 ft).

next, on the way home from school, despite it being a school trip, i saw 10 dogs running from behind. i managed to get past them, but then i saw 100 more coming. i said "to the city hall" and warped there.

it is needed to eliminate duplicate solutions to the 24 puzzle.
found that certain 19 rules can normalize an expr.

however, it didn't work for exprs whose value is 0 (or the 0 puzzle).
(due to an infinite loop.)

converts an expr by certain rules like
A * 1 * 1 ‚üπ A + 1 - 1.
i called the result the yuuki normal form (YNF).

defines exprs the same iff they have the same YNF.
i implemented this using Perl extended regexes.
https://github.com/yuuki15/24/blob/1c5d42beb24144c3fdcccb39f032eb6842395b05/normalize.pl#L87 https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1754567992543965231/photo/1

this is called a generating function n was discovered by de Moivre in the 18c, according to wiki.

seems using a‚Çô = a‚Çô‚Çã‚ÇÅ + a‚Çô‚Çã‚ÇÇ, it follows
ùëì(x) = x/(1 - x - x¬≤).

n some reasoning leads to
a‚Çô = (œï‚Åø - (-œï)‚Åª‚Åø)/‚àö5.

‚Ä¢ Recurrence relation
seems one way to find an exact formula for a sequence like
a‚Çô = 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, ‚Ä¶
is the ‚Äúinverse of the Taylor expansion.‚Äù

its known that
eÀ£ = 1/0! x‚Å∞ + 1/1! x¬π + 1/2! x¬≤ + ‚Ä¶,
but the idea is to find ùëì such that
ùëì(x) = 1x¬π + 1x¬≤ + 2x¬≥ + 3x‚Å¥ + ‚Ä¶.

0.999‚Ä¶=1 is obvious if the lhs is viewed as a limit.
there‚Äôs no doubt that 0.999‚Ä¶ is getting closer to 1.

‚Ä¢ Limit
lim[x‚Üí‚àû] f(x) = L
basically means that the point where the value gets closer (as x gets larger) is L.
nothing more, nothing less.
not smtg like ‚Äúequals L after infinite steps.‚Äù
(idk if such an interpretation is possible in higher math.)

‚Ä¢ Consider drawing a figure using only a function that draws a point (x,y) on a plane, say, drawPoint(x,y).

considering drawing a line leads to the equation of a line.

considering drawing a circle leads to trig functions.

however, it was discovered that this can be interpreted as the point (x,y) being moved to (e,f) by the matrix ((a,b),(c,d)). (by Cayley in the 19th century, according to wikipedia.)

so matrix multiplication represents the composition of maps f‚àòg, and so on.

My current understanding of mathematics.

‚Ä¢ Matrices are linear maps.
matrices were historically just a notation for simultaneous equations with coefficients and variables separated.

e.g. writing

ax + by = e
cx + dy = f

as

(a b)(x) = (e)
(c d)(y) = (f).

Seems this doesn't work in English since the word "capital" (È¶ñÈÉΩ usually translates to) has a broader meaning.
It was "what," not "where." More precisely, it could be the New York State Capitol in Albany.
So, in response to the question „Éã„É•„Éº„É®„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆÈ¶ñÈÉΩ„ÅØÔºü ("Where is the national capital of NY?"), answering „Ç™„Éº„É´„Éê„Éã ("Albany") would be a 2 level deep joke. i discovered this.
However, if we take the term È¶ñÈÉΩ ("national capital") simply as the capital (which is impossible in jpn), the closest would be Albany for NY.
"Where is the national capital of Europe?" also works. That line appears in the anime of Baka to Test to Shoukanjuu, season 1, episode 7.
In Japanese popular culture, there's a joke: "Where is the national capital of New York?" It expresses that the person is ignorant and mistakenly believes that NY is a country.
I discovered that the national capital of New York State („Éã„É•„Éº„É®„Éº„ÇØ„ÅÆÈ¶ñÈÉΩ) is Albany („Ç™„Éº„É´„Éê„Éã or „Ç¢„É´„Éê„Éã„Éº).

And I started attending Ayumi Nursery School probably on November 1, 1994.

This was because my mother (who was a nurse) had heard from my father (who was a hospital clerk) that she could get a winter bonus if she worked in November.

My parents named me Yuuki and my father registered my birth with Esashi as my place of residence.

We were discharged from the hospital after a week or so, lived in Karumai, and if I recall correctly, moved to Esashi six months later in November 1994.

The nearest Karumai Hospital doesn't have an OB/GYN.

Legend has it that on the night of the storm, my mother thought she was "about to give birth" and took a cab alone to the hospital.
My father was working alone in Esashi during that time.

My mother gave birth to me in her hometown.

This was because she had to leave my brother (who was 1 year and 11 months old at the time of my birth) with my grandparents.
I was born on May 17, 1994 at 1:56 a.m. at Iwate Prefectural Fukuoka Hospital in Ninohe, a city next to Karumai, my mother's hometown.

N*33 Kx P*13. Took me an hour to finally figure it out.
This is still easy. I'll try a more challenging problem next time.

P11 is the move here. If Kx, white can draw.
Black declines with K31.
Then N*21 is a trap.
Black appears to win with (a) P*22, but it leads to a loss with N33+.
Black still wins with (b) Lx, but P12! (below) is an incredible defense.
What should we do now? https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1638657556662087680/photo/1

The first move is Lx32. Responding to P22, we must drop N*33. This is the only way to win.
Then P23+ N21+ P33 N22 P23 Nx Kx K21 P13+ L31+ P12 L32 (below).
White's move here is the problem.
Amateur's is, for example, N*11 or K13. https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1638643570507927552/photo/1

Many pros would first consider Kx32 P-22 K-21 P-23+ L-31+ +P-22 K-11 K-23 (below).
However, black is already dead in this position.
Where did we go wrong? https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1638634543417815041/photo/1

Conclusion: Unclear. One theory is that Ë®Ä„ÅÜ is polysemous while Âëº„Å∂ is narrower, so the latter may have a slightly stronger meaning.

This addresses a different issue.
I think the answer and comment on it are correct. The second sentence is incorrect though. It should be Âêõ„Çí„Ç¢„Éõ„Å®Âëº„Å∂ without the „Å†.

Answer. I think this misses the point. Sure, Âëº„Å∂ is used more when it comes to people's names, but they doesn't say anything about what difference is there when describing a concept.
https://japanese.stackexchange.com/q/58260
The fact that "„Çí„Åç„Å§„Å≠„ÅÜ„Å©„Çì„Å®Âëº„Å∂" has more hits than "„Çí„Åç„Å§„Å≠„ÅÜ„Å©„Çì„Å®Ë®Ä„ÅÜ" seems to support my theory.

OTOH, I feel „Å®Âëº„Å∂ fits better to describe concrete concepts. E.g.,
Ê≤πÊèö„Åí„Åå‰πó„Å£„Åü„ÅÜ„Å©„Çì„Çí„Åç„Å§„Å≠„ÅÜ„Å©„Çì„Å®Âëº„Å∂„ÄÇ
(Udon with deep-fried tofu on top is called kitsune udon.)
One could argue that „Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ is "weak" here. No real difference, though.

On Twitter, however, it is sometimes easier to recognize word breaks by using kanji for such verbs, etc. Modern people tend to be unaware of such distinctions, as they type according to the keyboard app's conversion candidates.

The use of the hiragana „Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ here instead of „Å®Ë®Ä„ÅÜ is described in the Japanese Wikipedia's manual of style.
>ÂãïË©û„ÅÆ„ÅÜ„Å°„ÄÅÊú¨Êù•„ÅÆÊÑèÂë≥„Åå„Åª„Å®„Çì„Å©Â§±„Çè„Çå„Å¶„ÅÑ„Çã„ÇÇ„ÅÆ
"Verbs whose original meaning is almost lost [should be written in hiragana]"
https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:%E8%A1%A8%E8%A8%98%E3%82%AC%E3%82%A4%E3%83%89#%E4%BB%AE%E5%90%8D%E6%9B%B8%E3%81%8D

One thing came to my mind is „Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ may be used more to describe abstract concepts. E.g.,
3„Å§„ÅÆËæ∫„ÇíÊåÅ„Å§Â§öËßíÂΩ¢„Çí‰∏âËßíÂΩ¢„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜ„ÄÇ
(A polygon with three sides is called a triangle.)
Here „Å®Âëº„Å∂ is also perfectly fine, but may be "excessive", although the difference is slight.
Literally, „Å®Ë®Ä„ÅÜ may correspond to "said to be" and „Å®Âëº„Å∂ to "called", but the nuance could not be so. It could be the opposite, for example.

Someone tweeted "what is the difference between „Å®Ë®Ä„ÅÜ and „Å®Âëº„Å∂" and I found it difficult.
I thought it was similar to the difference between "is said to be", "is called", "is referred to as", etc. in English.

One drawback of Blogger is that you can't use your own domain; you can't run your blogspot domain and your own domain separately, so you need to use your blogspot domain to keep your blog running after your death.

This is my Blogger with the plain text theme applied.
It uses JavaScript to display posts, but it can be displayed without it (however, whitespace will be collapsed).
It is written in JavaScript 1.0, so it works on very old browsers.
https://yuukikonnobot.blogspot.com/
Blogger is ad-free and does not appear to have any plans to delete old blogs.

Then I came up with a hack to use Blogger's post by email feature.
If you discard your Google password and post via a secret email address, you can achieve such a blog.
I first created a WordPress theme that would do that, but there was no "once you sign up you can't cancel (i.e. it will keep running after your death)" ad-free hosting.
GitHub Pages + Jekyll cannot achieve "once posted, cannot be deleted".

In a blog where HTML code is available, I am so involved in decorating (e.g. displaying formulas nicely) that I cannot concentrate on writing the body of the article. Therefore, it needs to be plain text.
I need such blog software because I suffer from atelophobia and am tempted to delete old posts.
I was looking for a blog that was in plain text and that once posted, the post could not be edited or deleted. l had lost sight of that 5 months ago.

Five months later, today I released a Blogger theme.
https://github.com/plain-text-blogger-theme/plain-text-blogger-theme https://twitter.com/yuukikonnobot/status/1494571029481820161

There is a way to get the publication date using the GitHub API on the client side using JavaScript, assuming that the first commit date of the post file is considered the publication date.
However, this seems slow and I would not adopt it.

However, this method requires the installation of a scripting language and manipulation of the Terminal.
Naturally, the date cannot be obtained if the post file is created in the GitHub web interface.
One solution would be to register a script in Git's post-commit hook that would retrieve the creation date of the post file and store it somewhere.
Manually setting the publication date is tedious.
If the publication date is not set, the posts cannot be listed by date on the blog's home page.

One weakness of a blog based on Jekyll + GitHub Pages is that there is no way to automatically set the publication date.

WordPress and Blogger automatically set the date by simply posting a blog post. There is no way to accomplish this.

As a Dark-type attacker, it is strong against TGR, but weak in raids.
This is because of its Bite/Crunch moveset.
In raids, Snarl/Foul Play or Dark Pulse is stronger, which can be used by Mega Houndoom or Mega Absol.

As a Water-type attacker, Mega Gyarados is:
- In raids, it is inferior to Mega Blastoise against all known situations.
- Against TGR grunts, it is inferior to Mega Venusaur and Mega Aerodactyl (the difference is slight, though).

Mega Gyarados movesets
- Water: Unknown use.
- Dark: Fastest against Psychic TGR.
- Dragon: Fastest against Dragon TGR (tied with Galarian Darmanitan).

If I get a third hundo Magikarp, change to
1. Waterfall/Aqua Tail*/Hydro Pump,
then
3. Bite/Crunch.

I'm going to have my two Gyarados learn
1. Bite/Aqua Tail*/Crunch,
2. Dragon Tail*/Outrage.
AT and DT are legacy moves, so I want to prioritize them.

- Charm + Synchronoise and Shadow Ball (for PvP)

https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/issues/52461 https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1465810585929408512/photo/1
`get_primes' was wrong; it returned a prime > `x'. Maybe this is correct: https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1465806347291693057/photo/1
Starting from 5, which is the smallest integer > 3 that is not a multiple of 2 or 3, we get the following implementation: https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1465800885607354370/photo/1

Let q and r be integers.
Every integer n can be expressed as n = 6q + r where 0 <= r <= 5.
If r = 0, 2, or 4, then n is an even number.
If r = 3, then n is a multiple of 3.
Therefore, integers that are not a multiple of 2 or 3 are of the form either 6q + 1 or 6q + 5.

Further optimization.
Once we know that 2 is prime, we only need to look at integers that are not a multiple of 2, i.e., odd numbers.
Once we know that 2 and 3 are prime, we only need to look at integers that are not a multiple of 2 or 3.

`i <= sqrt_n' can also be written as `i * i <= n', but `i * i' can overflow.
By writing `i <= n / i', the overflow can be avoided.
Not sure which is faster, calculating `n / i' for each loop or pre-calculating `sqrt(n)'.
Now I can get the number of primes <= 10 million, 664579, in about 5 seconds. https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1465753381293547520/photo/1

Also, consider whether 113 is prime: it is not divisible by 2, 3, 5, 7, ... then there is no need to divide by 11.
If 113 = 11 * x, then x < 11 (because 11^2 = 121 > 113).
Thus, to test if n is prime, it is enough to divide by primes <= sqrt(n).
Ideally, to test if n is prime, we can divide it by primes <= n / 2, because if n has a composite divisor d, then n is divisible by a prime factor of d.

Let d != 0 and n be integers.
d is a divisor of n iff there exists an integer k such that n = kd.
In the above equation, for k > 1, d is maximized when k = 2, and then d = n/2. n/2 is not guaranteed to be an integer, but gives an upper bound. QED.
Also, it can be proved that the largest non-trivial divisor d of an integer n satisfies d <= n/2, and d = n/2 iff n is even, so `i < n / 2' is sufficient for `i < n' in `is_prime'.
Obviously, all primes except 2 are odd, and odd numbers are never divisible by even numbers, so I optimized for that: https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1465716865473212419/photo/1
Now my code looks like this. https://twitter.com/yuuki26/status/1465713325409386498/photo/1

Improvements to this are:
* The type of the argument for `is_prime' should be `const int'. According to SO, it is good practice to use `const' for constants as in JavaScript.
* For reusability, `main' should be factored out to "a function that returns a vector of primes <= x".

An integer n >= 2 is prime iff it is not divisible by any integer i where 2 <= i <= n - 1.
